message: What an incredible story and rescue. Keith Avila, an Uber driver in Sacramento, overheard two women in his car coaching a teenage girl on how to get money from a "john" on their way to a hotel. Once he dropped them off, he called the police, who arrested the two women at the hotel as well as a man who was found with the victim. The victim was a teenage runaway.   Putting an end to human trafficking will require being vigilant, keeping an eye out for suspicious situations, and taking proactive efforts to inform law enforcement like Keith did. We can all play a part in this effort. I hope the victim receives the help she needs and commend Keith for his heroism.   https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/inspired-life/wp/2016/12/30/an-eavesdropping-uber-driver-saved-his-16-year-old-passenger-from-her-pimps-police-say/?utm_term=.f51732f6813e

I am pleased to announce that my colleague Congressman Earl  Blumenauer and I have reintroduced the bipartisan Primary Care Enhancement Act. This initiative will help increase access to primary care physicians, an innovative and increasingly popular delivery model for many. This is one of many steps I am taking to ensure patients and families in Minnesota and across the country have access to health care that fits their needs.    https://paulsen.house.gov/press-releases/paulsen-blumenauer-introduce-bill-to-improve-access-to-primary-care23/

Today is National Human Trafficking Awareness Day. Human trafficking is a horrible practice that we must take action to end and provide support for its victims. I am proud of all the work we have accomplished to combat human trafficking, including my legislative initiatives (such as the Stop Exploitation Through Trafficking Act, which was signed into law by the President in the last Congress) and other efforts (such as my round table discussion last year with my congressional colleagues, stakeholder, and other leaders in the fight to stop human trafficking). We have made huge strides, but there is still more work to be done.  On this National Human Trafficking Awareness Day, I was honored to speak at an event with survivor leaders and advocates to protect victims. In honor of this day, I am also proud to be an original cosponsor on Congresswoman Ann Wagner's Trafficking Survivors Relief Act, which supports victims by allowing them to petition courts to have their criminal records cleared for crimes committed as a direct result of human trafficking. Together, we can end human trafficking.

The Star Tribune editorial board recognized my strong advocacy for trade and how it helps Minnesota and national economy:  "U.S. Rep. Erik Paulsen, R-Minn., who has been a consistent champion of expanding trade opportunities, made a good case for vital state support of trade when he told an editorial writer: 'The bottom line is for the economy continuing to grow, we can‚Äôt simply just buy American products. We‚Äôve also got to be selling American in growing markets. We can‚Äôt just walk away from the table from the [T-TIP] negotiations if we want to improve Minnesota‚Äôs economy ‚Äî we have to have a role in how these agreements are crafted.'  Paulsen's congressional colleagues should heed those words."  http://www.startribune.com/minnesota-can-t-afford-a-u-s-retreat-on-trade/411377045/

My statement on the President's recent executive order:  I support thorough vetting of those entering our country from countries and regions posing a serious threat to Americans. But this vetting must be applied responsibly and thoughtfully, and appropriately target those who are a national security risk. Unfortunately, the President's executive order is too broad and has been poorly implemented and conceived. It is clear from the events this weekend that the executive order does not ensure that legal residents, including green card holders, and non-threats, such as those who served alongside the American military in Iraq, are treated fairly and with the dignity they deserve.

Proud to cosponsor the bipartisan Blue Water Navy Vietnam Veterans Act by Congressman David Valadao to ensure our vets receive the health care they deserve. This initiative grants presumptive Agent Orange exposure status to U.S. military personnel who served in the territorial seas of Vietnam during the Vietnam War.

We've introduced the American Health Care Act to lower costs and empower individuals and families.  This initiative hits on three key reforms that I am glad to see. First, it repeals the harmful medical device tax, so that life-saving and -changing medical technologies will be more affordable and accessible for patients. Second, it enhances and expands Health Savings Accounts (HSAs) so that families and individuals can spend their health care dollars the way they want. Third, it provides a monthly tax credit to individuals and families who don't receive insurance from their jobs.  This effort also includes two provisions I am supportive of, such as preserving coverage for those with preexisting conditions and allowing 26-year-olds to stay on their parents‚Äô insurance.  Unlike the last time Congress took on health care reform, this is going to be an open and transparent process, so please visit ReadTheBill.gop to check out and read the bill for yourself.

My statement on the American Health Care Act:   "After many years and countless stories of patients facing skyrocketing premiums, losing their health care plan, and not being able to see their doctor, we are replacing Obamacare with a plan that will lower costs and give patients immediate relief. I am glad to see two initiatives that I helped lead ‚Äì the repeal of the harmful medical device tax as well as the enhancement and expansion of Health Savings Accounts ‚Äì included in these reforms, because they will help American families have access to high-quality health care."  https://paulsen.house.gov/press-releases/paulsen-backs-legislation-to-empower-patients-and-lower-health-care-costs/

Yesterday, I got a chance to check out new concept fire trucks from Ruff International Fire Truck that are cost- and water-efficient. It extinguishes fires with one-tenth of the water of conventional fire trucks. The demonstration was held at Hennepin Technical College's Eden Prairie campus in conjunction with the International Fire Relief Mission; the company is committed to dedicating 20 percent of vehicle sales to the Minnesota-based 501(c)(3) firefighting humanitarian group.

Today, I introduced an initiative to reduce obesity among seniors. The bipartisan Treat and Reduce Obesity Act, introduced with Congressman Ron Kind of Wisconsin, expands access to treatment options for Medicare beneficiaries afflicted with obesity and helps reduce health care costs. This year marks the 25th anniversary of the opening of the first charter school, which actually took place right in Minnesota. As co-chair of the Charter School Caucus, I am proud that our state is a leader in this area with 164 charter schools serving approximately 57,000 students in kindergarten through 12th grade. During National Charter Schools Week, I spoke on the House floor on why we must continue to work to ensure a child's zip code does not determine the quality of education they are able to receive.

We recently learned yet more troubling details surrounding the previous administration's Iran deal. According to reports, as part of the prisoner swap with Iran in 2016, the Obama administration released seven prisoners and dropped charges and international arrest warrants of 14 fugitives, many of whom had been directly involved in supplying Iran with US-built equipment or sensitive information that could be used for military systems, primarily Iran‚Äôs nuclear program. This was not made known to Congress or the American public. Like most, I support diplomatic efforts with Iran and am hopeful we can secure a good deal at some point, but not at the expense of the national security of the U.S. and our allies. But his latest news continues to exemplify why both Republicans and Democrats could not support this deal.

RELEASE: Paulsen Statement on the House Passage of Health Care Legislation  With millions in Minnesota and the United States in need of relief from skyrocketing costs, diminishing choices, and limited access, the status quo under Obamacare is no longer acceptable. This is just the latest step in reforming our health care system to be more patient-centered, and my focus remains on finding solutions that will make sure Americans have access to high quality, affordable health care. I‚Äôm also pleased to see the permanent repeal of the medical device tax included in this effort, which is critical to encourage medical innovation and make life-saving technologies accessible to patients.  https://paulsen.house.gov/press-releases/paulsen-statement-on-the-house-passage-of-health-care-legislation/

RELEASE: Paulsen Statement on the Firing of FBI Director Comey  "Maintaining public trust in the integrity of our elections as well as our institutions, such as the FBI, is of the utmost importance. For 10 months, the FBI has been investigating Russian interference in the 2016 election. The extraordinary decision to fire Director Comey definitely raises questions which must be answered. I believe these circumstances call for an independent investigation that the American people can trust with confidence."  https://paulsen.house.gov/press-releases/paulsen-statement-on-the-firing-of-fbi-director-comey/

RELEASE: Paulsen: Small Businesses Will Benefit from Reforming Our Broken Tax Code  "I continuously hear from Minnesota companies about the importance of having major tax reform that is permanent, that promotes investment, that lowers rates. It will boost paychecks, it will increase jobs, and it will grow the economy. Regardless of whether it‚Äôs a large or small company, these businesses, and the men and women working there, will benefit from fixing a broken tax code."  https://paulsen.house.gov/press-releases/paulsen-small-businesses-will-benefit-from-reforming-our-broken-tax-code/

On National Missing Children Day, we remember and continue to hold out hope for the boys and girls who have vanished, and the loved ones who miss them. As part of the recognition of this day, I spoke on the House Floor in support of the reauthorization of the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children. We also thank the law enforcement community for all of their hard work to help reunite lost children with their families. I am proud my Recovering Missing Children Act, which provides another tool for police to locate missing kids, was signed in to law last year to help families, loved ones, and children reach a happy ending during these scary episodes.

I recently thanked Living Word Christian Center Pastor Tim Burt on the House floor for his years of service to our community as he heads to retirement. He founded American Infant Care Products, which came up with the fold-down infant changing tables found in many restrooms today. He also served as Associate Pastor at Living Word Christian Center in Brooklyn Park for more than two decades and as the Minnesota State Director for Christians United for Israel. We are grateful for the work he has done and wish him and Renee the very best in the future.

Congratulations to Boren Awards for International Study recipients Elizabeth from Chanhassen and Xiaojing from Bloomington! It was great to meet with you both. This is a prestigious recognition from the National Security Education Program that they have earned: They will both be going to Africa to study abroad to focus on national security.

I was featured in this week's #TaxReformTuesday, which I did from Starkey Hearing in Eden Prairie. By modernizing our tax code, we can lift the economy through more jobs and higher wages for Minnesotans. As a member of the Ways and Means Committee, I look forward to advocating and pushing these ideas for tax reform out and want to hear your suggestions, too.

Last night on the House floor, I celebrated Esther Begam, a Holocaust survivor who was recently awarded her high school diploma from Wayzata High School at the age of 88. Esther has overcome incredibly difficult life challenges to be able to share this moving moment of receiving her diploma with her children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. Thank you to Wayzata HS for helping Esther fulfill her dream.

Just met with Colonel Polashek, Command Chief of the 934th Airlift Wing from Minnesota, also known as the Viking Wing, to discuss the importance of funding our Air Force Reserves. Thank you for your service and all you do.

From Prince to a mother in Maple Grove who lost her son, I discussed how the opioid epidemic does not discriminate and affects people from all walks of life during this morning's Joint Economic Committee hearing. Last year, I supported the bipartisan Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act to address the serious problem of opioid abuses in our communities. I also led a roundtable with Hennepin County Sheriff Rich Stanek that included local leaders and stakeholders to discuss strategies to curb this epidemic in Minnesota. While we have made a lot of progress in this fight, there is still more work to do.

Yesterday afternoon, I recognized all of the incredible men and women who won in their fights against cancer as part of National Cancer Survivors Day, which recently took place on June 4. Every year, thousands of lives are lost to this deadly disease. That‚Äôs why I supported the 21st Century Cures Act, which authorized $1.8 billion in funding for the Cancer Moonshot initiative. I‚Äôm committed to honoring more survivors through continuing to support research for new and improved cures.

I was honored to be a part of the commissioning of the USS Gabrielle Giffords this weekend in Galveston, Texas. What a great and special day for my friends Gabby Giffords and Mark Kelly. The newest and coolest Navy ship ‚öì congratulations!

Last week, I spoke on the House floor about the STAPLE Act, or the Stopping Trained in America Ph.Ds. from Leaving the Economy Act. This initiative makes a change to our outdated immigration policy by exempting foreign-born individuals who earn a Ph.D. in the STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) fields from the limits on the number of employment-based green cards and H-1B visas awarded annually. It allows the brilliant minds that we educated in the U.S. to stay and contribute to our economy rather than return to their home countries and compete with us. This step will encourage further American innovation and help jobs and families here at home.
I join our nation in mourning the seven @USNavy service members who died aboard the USS Fitzgerald in Japan this weekend. Their service will not be forgotten.

Yesterday, I voted to improve our child welfare and foster care systems in order to help and protect our most vulnerable. These initiatives strengthen families and our communities as well as, most importantly, provide a safe, stable home for children.

Last night, I recognized Alzheimer's & Brain Awareness Month on the House floor. This is an important fight that affects so many Americans and people around the world. That's why I've continued to push for research funding and treatment. Last year, I took part in the Walk 2 End Alzheimer's event at Target Field and saw the passion of 12,000 advocates also fighting for a cure. Together, we can #endALZ.

During this morning's Ways and Means Committee hearing with United States Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer, I spoke about the importance of promoting a robust trade agenda. As the co-chair of the Congressional Digital Trade Caucus, I highlighted the rapidly changing economy and emphasized the need for American trade policy to modernize along with it. I also encouraged Lighthizer to ensure that U.S. trade policy encourages medical innovation that benefits American businesses and workers.

Service dogs are proven to help our veterans with PTSD, which is why I'm cosponsoring the PAWS Act. Under this initiative, the VA will create a five-year program to give organizations grants to pair veterans suffering with PTSD with a service dog to increase their recovery. It is imperative that we place our veterans' mental health as a high priority and that they have access to as many options as possible.

On the House floor today, I spoke on addressing the student-debt crisis by expanding access to higher education with an affordable approach. Income-share agreements, or ISAs, allow students to pay back of small portion of their loan depending on their income. Rather than having to keep up with fixed, high-interest payments, which can be particularly stressful amid job uncertainty for recent graduates, the freedom and flexibility that ISAs provide students allows them to pursue careers that put their degrees in to practice. That's why I'm sponsoring the Investing in Student Success Act to create more options for payment and therefore increases accessibility to higher education.

On the House floor this week, I remembered the life of Kate Fronek, who passed away from complications with acute myeloid leukemia last week at the age of 13. Kate attended Central Middle School in Eden Prairie, was an avid music lover, and played hockey, lacrosse, and soccer. Her friends and family all remember her positive attitude and bright smile. She touched many lives and people all throughout the community have put orange balloons outside their homes to honor her memory. My thoughts and prayers are with the Fronek family and all loved ones. Kate will be very missed, but certainly not forgotten.

I am excited to announce this year's The Congressional App Challenge for MN-03 students! This Challenge gives young innovators a chance to show off their tech skills and knowledge. Launching today, the Challenge runs through November 1 and our district's winner receives Congressional recognition and will be featured in the Capitol. For more information, go to http://www.congressionalappchallenge.us/. Best of luck to everyone!

This is a valuable resource in the effort to put an end to human trafficking. It sheds light on the fact that, as the lead researcher puts it, buyers "are really part of mainstream society" and buying at all times of day throughout the state. As I've said before, these sex-trafficking operations are sadly more prevalent and closer to home than we may realize. Hopefully continued focus and investment on this issue can stop this horrible practice. I commend the U as well as all others involved in this study on their work.

As I said over the weekend, I am so relieved to hear that no one was hurt in events at the Dar Al-Farooq Islamic Center on Saturday morning. My office and I have been monitoring this ongoing investigation and been in contact with Dar Al-Farooq. I have full confidence that the investigation will get to the bottom of this and am encouraged by the progress the FBI as well as local and state authorities are making to make sure justice is served. Any attack of this nature is an affront to our American and Minnesotan values, and we will continue supporting the Dar Al-Farooq and Muslim community.
The outpouring of support for Dar Al-Farooq in Bloomington this evening shows a community is there for them. They are not alone; we are united.

There is no place in civil, respectful society for the horrid views expressed and violence taking place in Charlottesville. We must be united as a country, not divided by bigotry.  UPDATE: The driving of a car through a crowd of people today was an act of domestic terrorism. My thoughts are with the victims and their loved ones. We must reject all forms of bigotry, by white supremacist groups or any group that attempts to spread hate and violence.
Met with leaders of different faiths this morning. We came together to discuss recent events as well as refugee resettlement. Thank you for your time and insights.
Today, I learned about Fairview's Tele-ICU system that remotely monitors ICU patients around the state. It saved 134 lives last year from deadly infections.

I visited Dar Al-Farooq Islamic Center yesterday. Their resilience and strength in the face of this month's bombing has been inspiring, as has the community's support for them. They are determined to rebuild, and I have full confidence that they will.  In case you missed it, the FBI is asking for help in their probe on the bombing, so if you have any information, please contact them at 1-800-CALL-FBI. Justice must be served.

This morning, the Wayzata and Long Lake community, along with law enforcement from across Minnesota, paid their respects to fallen Officer William Mathews, who was tragically struck last Friday while removing hazardous debris from Highway 12. A true public servant, Office Mathews was a nine-year veteran of the Wayzata Police Department, and served two decades in law enforcement through the state. As dedicated a police officer as he was, he was an even more devoted husband and father. We mourn with his wife, Shawn, and his seven-year-old son, Wyatt. Last night, I honored Officer Mathews on the House floor. Office Mathews lost his life in service to his community and he will not be forgotten.

I was so honored and moved to take part in the ribbon-cutting ceremony for the Veterans East Housing Community this afternoon. This new 100-unit apartment building will provide affordable housing for chronically homeless veterans. While the number of homeless veterans in Minnesota has gone down in recent years, there is still more work to be done, especially because of the sacrifice our brave men and women have made for their country by serving. This new complex will help in this effort to show our veterans our gratitude. Thank you again to our veterans and I was so touched to have taken part in this powerful event.

Today, I helped deliver some Meals on Wheels America lunches around Mound with WeCAN - Western Communities Action Network. It was great to meet people like Helen and Chuck who benefit from such an important program. That's why I proudly supported a bipartisan appropriations bill last week that increased funding to Meals on Wheels so that the most vulnerable in our society are getting the nutrition, food security, and quality of life that they need. Hope you enjoyed your meals, Helen and Chuck!

Minnesota‚Äôs economy has changed a lot since 1986. We‚Äôre producing $225 billion more than we used to, and we‚Äôre earning almost $141 billion more. Why are we still using the same broken tax code? Imagine what we could accomplish with a newer tax code that doesn‚Äôt trap us in a maze of write-offs and loopholes. It‚Äôs time to simplify things and come up with a tax code that serves both our workers and our employers. Click here to learn more about a plan that works for everyone: https://fairandsimple.gop/?utm_source=Erik%20Paulsen

September is Peripheral Artery Disease Month, and a great opportunity to call attention to a disease that affects 18 million Americans. Last night, I spoke on the House floor about the impacts of PAD and the need for a comprehensive strategy for improving the lives of its victims.

We‚Äôve achieved a lot since 1986. We landed a rover on Mars and mapped the human genome. The U.S. has come a long way, but there‚Äôs one challenge that still remains: Reforming our tax code. Our tax system has become bloated and confusing, weakening our businesses and our workers. Fixing the tax code won‚Äôt be easy, but it‚Äôs time we faced this challenge with the same spirit and enthusiasm that‚Äôs allowed Americans to triumph in the past.   Tomorrow, we will be releasing more details, but you can click here to get a sneak peek at our plan to write a newer, cleaner tax code: https://fairandsimple.gop/?utm_source=Erik%20Paulsen

This is an exciting week for Minnesota‚Äôs middle-class families and small businesses. After more than three decades since the last major tax reform, the framework released today outlines how fixing our broken tax code will lead to more jobs and bigger paychecks. Tax reform is about one thing: Restoring the hope of prosperity for American workers, their families, and, most importantly, the next generation. Learn more here: https://fairandsimple.gop/
A simpler tax code is a better tax code for you and your family. Learn more about how individuals and families can save here: https://fairandsimple.gop/?utm_source=Erik%20Paulsen

On Sunday, we marked the 31st anniversary of President Reagan signing tax reform into law. That was so long ago, Minnesota landmarks like I-394, the Carlson Towers, and Mall of America didn't exist! Our state and national economies have transformed dramatically since then, but our tax code has only gotten more bloated and confusing. To see how we plan to modernize and simplify the tax code, click here: https://fairandsimple.gop/?utm_source=Erik%20Paulsen

On the House floor earlier this week, I recognized Good Karma Animal Rescue of MN in Maple Grove for their animal rescue efforts in the wake of Hurricane Harvey. They made two separate rescue trips and rescued over fifty animals, who are now being treated and prepared for adoption by Minnesota families.

After passing a budget in the House today, Congress is one step closer to reforming our tax code and revitalizing our economy. This was a victory for Minnesota families who want more jobs, simpler taxes, and bigger paychecks. I recently heard from small businesses in our community which were enthusiastic about investing more in their own companies and growing their local economies. I'm happy to say that this morning's vote was a significant step towards that goal.

During today‚Äôs #TaxReform markup hearing, I discussed how the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act will provide tax relief to Minnesotans, and Americans as a whole. The reality of this tax reform proposal is that its benefits are aimed at working and middle-income families, regardless of what you might hear about this bill. People living paycheck-to-paycheck will see an increase in their wages while small businesses will be allowed to keep more of what they earn to give their employees raises and hire more people. See my full questions and comments during today‚Äôs markup:

Our new Tax Reform bill, the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act is win for Minnesota. Analysis from the Tax Foundation shows that our plan would create more than 19,000 new jobs and raise median household income by over $3,000. In Minnesota's Third Congressional District, the news is even better: median household income for a family of four is going up by over $5,000, according to a new Ways and Means Committee analysis. That's the kind of economic boost we know our local and state economies need.

On Veteran's Day, we take this opportunity to think about the brave men and women who have served our country to protect our freedom and all we hold dear. The sacrifices made, the struggles endured, and the challenges overcome by these heroes in uniform are what keep us safe. We also recognize their loved ones who joined in that sacrifice.   To the Army, Navy, Marine, Air Force, Coast Guard, and National Guard veterans living in Minnesota and throughout the U.S: Thank you. We owe you a debt that can never be repaid.

Pregnancy-related and pregnancy-associated deaths are tragically overlooked in the United States. We have the highest maternal mortality rate of any developed country, and are the only country where maternal deaths continue to rise. That's why I support the Preventing Maternal Deaths Act, which gives states tools & resources to prevent these deaths.

Today's passage of historic tax reform marks a new beginning for hardworking, middle-income Americans who will be able to keep more of the money they earn, better provide for their families, and save for retirement. Families and businesses across the country will no longer be held back by a broken, outdated tax code and can instead have hope in a prosperous future. In my remarks before today's vote, I recognized my friend and mentor, former MN-03 Congressman Bill Frenzel, the last Minnesotan to serve on the Ways and Means Committee during passage of a once-in-a-generation tax reform bill.
